channel.title: Native coding
channel.description: Alright well the new question at hand is just for someone to give me a code that will let me control the flashing, the code has to be in native.. or however u say it

item.title: Native coding
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

[quote=“chrisn2323, post:15, topic:211824”]java.awt.Window.toFront()

lulz google searched it in less than 15 secs.[/quote]
apparently you think im retarded… if you’ve ever tried (or read what the poepl said on there) you would know that it will not blink if you are looking at anot her window made in the same ?process? as the window wanting to go to the foreground. Say i was typing in Messenger window produced by my messenger and that someone messaged me… that window would appear in front of all the other java windows and interrupt my message typing… which would be annoyihng…

and lawl, thats a nice discovery, but if i wanted to minimize the window everytime i wanted to flash it, i would just use toFront()… idk… i’ll see if that wud work better

Read full topic

item.title: Native coding
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“pizza pie, post:9, topic:211824”]Well, can someone please give me a code that can be used in the JNIWrapper so that I can convert them to Java? Its really pissing me off. I tried so many different types… nothing worked.

All I need it to be able to do is 1. flash 3 times. 2. stay lit. 3. and allow me to turn it off when it regains the focus, if it doesnt do that already…

at least something close to that. Please?[/quote]

Use this:

eclipse.org

SWT: The Standard Widget Toolkit | The Eclipse Foundation

The Eclipse Foundation - home to a global community, the Eclipse IDE, Jakarta EE and over 350 open source projects, including runtimes, tools and frameworks.

This sounds like a related newgroup post.

http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform.swt/msg24968.html

Read full topic

item.title: Native coding
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

Well, can someone please give me a code that can be used in the JNIWrapper so that I can convert them to Java? Its really pissing me off. I tried so many different types… nothing worked.

All I need it to be able to do is 1. flash 3 times. 2. stay lit. 3. and allow me to turn it off when it regains the focus, if it doesnt do that already…

at least something close to that. Please?

Read full topic

item.title: Native coding
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

Oh, lol. Wow. I thought you were talking about the actual MSN Messenger. I haven’t used it for a bit, so I forgot if it flashes or not.

To check for focus is very simple:
new Window(myFrame).isFocused()

I’m sure you can figure out how to play a sound. Even a simple java.awt.Toolkit.beep() would work.

As for the flashing, you’re going to have to resort to native API.

Read full topic

item.title: Native coding
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

Oh tyvm Telenubby but I meant on my messenger.

right now i’m on my last attempt because i really have working with stupid win32 crap… im trying javax.swing.timer… but for some reason when i try to compile it says that javax.swing.plaf.ColorUIResource doesn’t exist. is it only JDK1.6u6 cuz i got u5… dam this is gay

Read full topic

item.title: Native coding
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

Well, to see if the message comes, you can create a quick packet sniffer in Java. There’s even a good public API if you want one (http://netresearch.ics.uci.edu/kfujii/jpcap/doc/).

Next, you’ll want to read about the MSN protocol to find out what triggers the client to identify the incoming command as a ‘message’ (a good documention on the protocol can be found here: http://www.hypothetic.org/docs/msn/)

So now, you can run your program to sniff out the sessions between the messenger and server, and if a message is received, you’ll be able to know that.

According to you, the next step would be to play a sound and set focus if the window is not already focused. I’m afraid I do not know of anything that would get a Window instance (or anything similar) of a Window that YOU did not create in Java (so anything not in Java) using the Java API off the top of my head. But I also do doubt there is anything directly there for you to use. You’ve probably got a better chance using Native API. If I find anything, I’ll tell you.

Read full topic

item.title: Native coding
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I see what you mean. Well… the thing is, even if they DID provide a way to do this without using native code, you’d be sacrificing platform independence anyway, seeing as Windows is the only OS where you have a “taskbar icon” for definite.

Read full topic
